properties.name: National Mall and Memorial Parks
properties.notes:
National Mall and Memorial Parks https://www.nps.gov/places/crnama.htm

Officially established in 1965, National Mall and Memorial Parks contains some of the oldest protected park lands in the National Park Service. The sprawling lands include the Mall, the public promenade extending from 3rd Street near the Capitol to 14th Street. The National Mall is the continuation of that space where congressionally authorized park icons, such as the Washington Monument, WWII and Lincoln Memorials stand. This historic expanse is the linear area between the Potomac River and Capital Reflecting Pool. In addition to the memorial core, the park includes some 156 reservations, circles, fountains and other open spaces, all of which serve as the nation’s front yard. Ford’s Theatre, The House where Lincoln died, Potomac Park, Hains Point and Pennsylvania Avenue NHS are also among the park managed areas that constitute National Mall and Memorial Parks.

Having over 1,000 acres of National Park Service managed land at the heart of our nation’s capital, National Mall and Memorial Parks provides visitors with abundant opportunities to get in touch with our heritage. With everything from colossal monuments to commemorative gardens, from presidential inaugurals to civil rights demonstrations, National Mall and Memorial Parks hosts history in the making. Numerous First Amendment activities and special events are held in the park each year to honor the courage, sacrifice and devotion to duty of war veterans; celebrate the United States commitment to freedom, equality and democratic ideals; and enjoy symbolic architecture, historic vistas and renowned natural landscapes.

properties.name: Northeast Portico
properties.notes:
Northeast Portico https://www.nps.gov/places/northeast-chamber-panel.htm

The quotes below show, in their entirety, the correspondents and writings of Thomas Jefferson that appear as excerpts on the northeast chamber panel. 

"But let them [members of the parliament of Great Britain] not think to exclude us from going to other markets, to dispose of those commodities which they cannot use, nor41 to supply those wants which they cannot supply. Still less let it be proposed that our properties within our own territories shall be taxed or regulated by any power on earth but our own. The god who gave us life gave us liberty at the same time: the hand of force may destroy, but cannot disjoin them." - "A Summary View of the Rights of British America"

"For in a warm climate, no man will labour for himself who can make another labour for him. This is so true, that of the proprietors of slaves a very small proportion indeed are ever seen to labor. And can the liberties of a nation be thought secure when we have removed their only firm basis, a conviction in the minds of the people that these liberties are the gift of God? That they are not to be violated but with his wrath? Indeed I tremble for my country when I reflect that God is just: that his justice cannot sleep for ever . . . ." - Notes on the State of Virginia, Query XVIII

"The whole commerce between master and slave is a perpetual exercise of the most boisterous passions, the most unremitting despotism on the one part, and degrading submissions on the other. Our children see this, and learn to imitate it. . . ." - Notes on the State of Virginia, Query XVIII

"Nothing is more certainly written in the book of fate than that these people are to be free. Nor is it less certain that the two races, equally free, cannot live in the same government. Nature, habit, opinion has drawn indelible lines of distinction between them." - Jefferson's Autobiography

"Preach, my dear sir, a crusade against ignorance; establish & improve the law for educating the common people." - Jefferson to George Wythe, August 13, 1786 

"It is an axiom in my mind that our liberty can never be safe but in the hands of the people themselves, and that too of the people with a certain degree of instruction. This it is the business of the state to effect, and on a general plan." - Jefferson to George Washington, January 4, 1786

properties.name: Northwest Portico
properties.notes:
Northwest Portico https://www.nps.gov/places/northwest-portico.htm The northwest portico wall houses a snippet of the Thomas Jefferson's BIll for Establishing Religious Freedom. Below one can find the full text.

"Well aware that the opinions and belief of men depend not on their own will, but follow involuntarily the evidence proposed to their minds; that Almighty God hath created the mind free, and manifested his supreme will that free it shall remain by making it altogether insusceptible of restraint; that all attempts to influence it by temporal punishments, or burthens, or by civil incapacitations, tend only to beget habits of hypocrisy and meanness, and are a departure from the plan of the holy author of our religion...Be it enacted by the General Assembly that no man shall be compelled to frequent or support any religious worship, place, or ministry whatsoever, nor shall be enforced, restrained, molested, or burthened in his body or goods, nor shall otherwise suffer, on account of his religious opinions or belief; but that all men shall be free to profess, and by argument to maintain, their opinions in matters of religion, and that the same shall in no wise diminish, enlarge, or affect their civil capacities." - "A Bill for Establishing Religious Freedom", Section I

properties.name: Southeast Portico
properties.notes:
Southeast Portico https://www.nps.gov/places/southeast-portico.htm

"I am certainly not an advocate for frequent and untried changes in laws and constitutions. I think moderate imperfections had better be borne with; because, when once known, we accommodate ourselves to them, and find practical means of correcting their ill effects. But I know also, that laws and institutions must go hand in hand with the progress of the human mind. As that becomes more developed, more enlightened, as new discoveries are made, new truths disclosed, and manners and opinions change with the change of circumstances, institutions must advance also, and keep pace with the times. We might as well require a man to wear still the coat which fitted him when a boy, as civilized society to remain ever under the regimen of their barbarous ancestors." - Jefferson to H. Tompkinson (AKA Samuel Kercheval), July 12, 1816 

The Inscription an excerpt of a letter from Jefferson to Samuel Kercheval. This selection emphasis Thomas Jefferson’s belief in the need for government to continue to change and evolve for the benefit of society.

properties.name: Southwest Portico – Declaration of Independence
properties.notes:
Southwest Portico – Declaration of Independence
https://www.nps.gov/places/southwest-chamber-panel.htm

The Southwest panel highlights selections from the United States Declaration of Independence. The quote is written in chronological order as it was in the original document. This is different from the other quotes on the wall.

properties.name: Statue of Thomas Jefferson and the Symbology on the statue
properties.notes:
Statue of Thomas Jefferson and the Symbology on the statue https://www.nps.gov/places/statue-of-thomas-jefferson-and-the-symbology-on-the-statue.htm New York sculptor artist Rudolph Evans was selected by the Thomas Jefferson Memorial Commission to undertake the portrait statue of Thomas Jefferson. The 19’ tall bronze statue was installed in April of 1947, replacing the original statue which due to wartime restrictions on the use of precious metals, was made of plaster-of-Paris. What is Jefferson looking at? The statue faces north towards the White House which he lived in as our Third President. Jefferson also looks toward the monument to his fellow Virginia revolutionary, George Washington. Some point out that Jefferson may be keeping a wary eye on Alexander Hamilton, his great political foe. Hamilton's statue, by James Earle Fraser, is on the south side of the U.S. Treasury Building.

If one were to walk behind the Thomas Jefferson statue, several things appear to confirm Jefferson's love of the land and agriculture. These interest are represented by a stack of books and stalks of corn.

properties.name: The Corner Stone and Time Capsule
properties.notes:
The Corner Stone and Time Capsule
https://www.nps.gov/places/the-corner-stone-time-capsule.htm

On Dec. 15, 1938, President Franklin D. Roosevelt participated in the groundbreaking ceremony for the Thomas Jefferson Memorial. One year later, on Nov. 15, 1939, with the foundation work completed, President Roosevelt returned to place the memorial cornerstone & time capsule. FDR used the same Masonic trowel George Washington had used in laying the cornerstone of the U.S. Capitol Building.

properties.name: The Memorials Around the Tidal Basin
properties.notes:
The Memorials Around the Tidal Basin https://www.nps.gov/places/the-memorials-around-the-tidal-basin.htm

The Jefferson, Roosevelt, and King memorials connect, both chronologically and thematically, clockwise around the Tidal Basin. 
 

Thomas Jefferson lived April 13, 1743 – July 4, 1826. 

The memorial was authorized by Congress on June 26, 1934.  

Official dedication date: April 13, 1943 
 

Franklin Delano Roosevelt lived January 30, 1882 – April 12, 1945. 

The memorial was authorized by Congress on August 11, 1955. 

Official dedication date: May 2, 1997 
 

Martin Luther King, Jr. Lived January 15, 1929 – April 4, 1968. 

The memorial was authorized by Congress on November 12, 1996. 

Official dedication date: August 28, 2011 

The Declaration of Independence, adopted on July 4, 1776, set forth ideals for this country. Many of Roosevelt’s New Deal programs provided economic opportunity for those that needed help. King’s work in the Civil Rights Movement to attain fairer social and economic opportunity sought to make the ideals contained in the Declaration of Independence a reality for all Americans. The beginning and end goal are one.

properties.name: The Tympanum (triangular area above the entrance of the memorial)
properties.notes:
The Tympanum (triangular area above the entrance of the memorial)
https://www.nps.gov/places/the-tympanum-triangular-area-at-the-entrance-of-the-memorial.htm

In the Tympanum is a bas-relief sculpture by Adolf Weinman depicting the Committee of Five tasked on June 11, 1776, with writing a Declaration of Independence. The members of the committee included Thomas Jefferson of Virginia, Roger Sherman of Connecticut, Benjamin Franklin of Pennsylvania, Robert R. Livingston of New York, and John Adams of Massachusetts.

properties.name: Thomas Jefferson Memorial
properties.notes:
Thomas Jefferson Memorial https://www.nps.gov/places/000/thomas-jefferson-memorial.htm

Thomas Jefferson (1743-1826) was the third president of the United States, Secretary of State in George Washington's cabinet, and the author of the Declaration of Independence. Begun as a New Deal construction project, the Thomas Jefferson Memorial was completed in 1943. The imposing marble structure's columns and Monticello-esque dome bear selections of Jefferson's writings on several themes including religion, education, freedom, and government. Additional exhibits and restrooms are located on the lower level.

properties.name: Thomas Jefferson Memorial Commission and Planners
properties.notes:
Thomas Jefferson Memorial Commission and Planners
https://www.nps.gov/places/the-names-of-the-members-of-the-thomas-jefferson-memorial-commission-and-other-planners.htm

This engraving identifies the members of the all-white male Thomas Jefferson Memorial Commission and those responsible for the planning, design, and construction of the Thomas Jefferson Memorial. Can you guess which members of the commission were descendants of Thomas Jefferson? The three names most important to the story of the Thomas Jefferson Memorial are John J. Boylan as commission chairman; Fiske Kimball as the noted expert on Thomas Jefferson’s architectural career; and John Russell Pope the architect.

properties.name: Thomas Jefferson Memorial Plaza
properties.notes:
Thomas Jefferson Memorial Plaza https://www.nps.gov/places/center-of-the-thomas-jefferson-memorial-plaza.htm

With its view of the White House, the location south of the Washington Monument along the Tidal Basin was regarded as the last undeveloped site for a significant memorial within the core composition of the National Mall. The final spot of honor was of interest to many. A proposed Theodore Roosevelt Memorial project had failed in 1925 leaving this location available ten years later. In 1935 the Thomas Jefferson Memorial Commission was determined to secure the site to fulfill the proposed design laid out by the 1901 McMillan Plan.

properties.name: Thomas Jefferson Memorial Rotunda
properties.notes:
Thomas Jefferson Memorial Rotunda https://www.nps.gov/places/thomas-jefferson-memorial-rotunda.htm

"...I have sworn upon the altar of god eternal hostility against every form of tyranny over the mind of man." - Jefferson to Dr. Benjamin Rush, September 23, 1800 

All the chamber inscriptions are taken from the writings of Thomas Jefferson. This inscription consists of three-foot tall letters carved into the interior marble wall at the bottom of the rotunda. These words underscore Thomas Jefferson as an American contributor to the Enlightenment movement of the 18th Century, and his belief in the primacy of the power of the human mind.

properties.name: Thomas Jefferson Memorial: Statue of Jefferson
properties.notes:
Thomas Jefferson Memorial: Statue of Jefferson https://www.nps.gov/places/000/thomas-jefferson-memorial-statue-of-jefferson.htm

This bronze designed by Rudulph Evans depicts Thomas Jefferson holding a rolled piece of paper, suggesting his stature as a man of words. Head to the rear of the statue to find hidden features including crops and books that serve as the foundation of Jefferson's worldview.
